content.description:
Start as you would for Banga, but step right off the large boulder onto the face.  The crux comes quick moving from the 3rd to the 4th bolt and involves a large move to a right hand crimp - much easier if you are tall.  From here, sustained climbing on crimps and little flakes with the occasional pocket.  A large jug rest at two-thirds height let’s you get it all back before the last few bolts of sustained face climbing.

This is an excellent route and would be deserving of 3.5 stars if not for the large, loose blocks just left of the resting jug mentioned above.  Luckily, they are easily avoidable.  Also, the rock quality decreases a bit for the upper third and becomes somewhat dusty.

Worth doing!
content.protection: Bolts, fixed lower offs at the anchor

content.description: Follow the crack.
Not sure if holds were broken off this route or what, but it seems very stiff for the 5.7 grade. I led a 5.8 and a 5.9 just to the right of this route, and they seemed much easier.
content.protection: 6 bolts and open shuts for anchors
content.location: Take approach trail up to the base of the wall and turn left. HDC 204 is the first route on the face right of HDC 203. HDC 203 is located on a slabby part on the far left side of the Hound Dog Crag. HDC 205 to the right of HDC 204 is a bolted 5.9 crack.

content.description:
Thin, sharp pockets mark the start of this route.

Start right of the bolt line and move up and left towards the giant flake over the roof.  Pull the roof while trying to clip the next bolt to the right and not worrying about the sketchy flake ;)  Get established at a stance before the thinness kicks in hard.  Pick a line (think of dualing side-pulls) and punch it through to the broken flake-edge up and to the right.  Keep it cool to the top.
content.protection: Twelve bolts to a two-bolt anchor.
content.location: This route is located on the left side of a section of wall near the middle of the Hound Dog Crag.  The wall is marked by a roof that tapers in width toward both sides of the wall section.  It is to the left of Otter Hound, which is a 5.12+ that takes the right side of the roof on this wall.

content.description: Awesome route! Follows the line of bolts near a seam/crack. Easier climbing up ledges, then the climbing gets more difficult after 4th bolt. After pulling the small roof, fight the pump (crux) to the anchors.

climbs.name: Pulling Chest Hair
climbs.fa: Jake Marlow, Austin Yeoman, Beau Byrd

content.description:
I am not really sure if this is a first ascent or not so if you know do tell!

Eager to relish in the irony of climbing a crack in a fantastic sport area, we decided to climb a crack. The first part is a pretty straight forward left side in chimney. The hand crack starts going around the slight bulge with solid holds until you top out into some plants and dirt. Chimney up a little more until you are level with the anchors for route 214 in the book. This is where the fun part starts (hence the R rating). Place pieces where ever possible. I placed a blue dragon cam and a #3 nut in a flake in in the chimney and used 120cm slings to alleviate rope drag. Traverse on marginal protection yet surprisingly secure holds to the route 214 anchors and descend.
content.protection:
What I used:

purple power cam

yellow link cam

#4 camp hex

little blue dragon cam on a 120cm sling

#3 trango nut also on a 120cm sling

in that order.

content.description: Good holds on slightly overhanging face
content.location: Just left of Big Bear Memorial

content.description: Between Bulldog Arete and Mufassa. Climb a slab to an overlap with a large detached flake gaurding the bulge. Sneak past the sketch flake and gain the beautiful upper wall. Pumpy climbing on excellent stone takes you to the anchor.
Head up the short crack to the blank face above.  It is easy to move right at the crux and jion the arete.
content.location: First route on the right on the short pillar to the left of Banga.

content.description: Great bolted crack that allows for a safe and fun combination of face climbing, crack jams, and some stemming. Great ledge to stand on up top to enjoy the view.
content.location: Take right at the top of the approach trail. Routes follows the crack dihedral just to the left of the leaning column of rock that forms a small cave.

content.description: Solid 5.6/5.9, 2 pitch route. This is a great route for those getting into multi-pitch climbing. The first pitch is a solid 5.6. The second pitch is a pretty easy 5.9.
content.protection: Great bolted protection. Both anchors have excellent bolts.
content.location: Route starts at the bottom of a slab.

content.description: Technical crux is 2/3 up first crack section off of the initial block.  There are a couple additional boulder problems in the 2nd half of the route, but they are between good rests.  Cool, varied line with flowy movement after the bouldery crack part.
content.protection: 10ish bolts to a cold shuts anchor.
content.location: Directly left of "Banga".  Locate the big block off the ground where there's one bolt on the top-left of it, and one bolt on the top-right.  The bolt on the top right is for "Banga", while the bolt on the top-left is for this route.

content.description: Yet another great route! Start up the base of the arete, then follow the bolts just left of the arete. Crimper crux with good rests.
Climb the right side of the ramp, following the bolts up on to the face.
content.location: bolted route to the left of Munsterlander, right of Afghan Hound.

content.description: Start on long moves in crack.  After a few bolts break right out of crack (with very bad feet) and continue up technical face.  Stiff.
content.location: Near the top of the main trail up to HDC

content.description: Obvious route up the arete on pockets and edges.  Looks short but is very involved and feels longer because its quite sustained
content.location:
Right of Doberman Face, left of Middle of the Road.

The cool steep arete in the middle of the wall.

content.description: Technical Face climb on tiny crimps. Low Crux moving past 2nd to 3rd bolts and continuous hard climbing on small holds to the top.
content.location: First bolted line to the left of the Arete climb Norwegian Lundehund. Starts at the seam that quickly vanishes.

content.description:
Super thin (and interesting) start. Nothing pumpy, all techy and precise positionning will do the trick. The guidebook says 11+. I would say it's definitely an 11d. The first part is somewhat reminescent of B1 Bomber Dude @ Chaos Buttress, just harder.

The issue with this route is the top part, which is crazy sharp and not much fun to climb for that reason.
content.location: Next to Saluki and just left of the huge crack.

content.description:
Funky stem-slabbin' marks the start of this route (a little trickier than it looks).  The start is actually "Afghan Hound" to the first set of anchors, but it is rated 5.9 also and a 60-meter rope will get you down.  Why not just do the next section.  It's better climbing anyway.

Climb left up one slabby crack-corner to a break and then proceed up-and-right to another steeper crack-corner that then evolves into pocketed face climbing.  Move out right to the anchors.
content.protection: Twenty-two bolts to a two-bolt anchor.
content.location: The farthest left route on main section of the far right side of the Hound Dog Crag (not including routes to the left of the large pillar).

content.description: Easily one of the best 5.10's around.  Stemming with jugs up a dihedral that just keeps going and going.  Pure fun with a cruxy move right at the end.  GET ON IT!!  (Tie a knot in the end of a 60 meter rope).
content.protection: 15 bolts plus anchors. New anchors courtesy Bighorn Anchor Initiative.
content.location: Furthest right route at the Hound Dog Crag, up the dihedral.

content.description: Start up big block (first bolt near the top of it) and up the route in crack on right.
Pretty soft 5.9 crack/face climbing passed a few anchors to the start of HDC 220. Two pitches can be done with one 70 M rope.
content.location: Take a right after the approach trail to the leaning pillar. Walk through the cave and the route starts just after the cave. Climb a slabby crack with stemming to gain the better 2nd pitch. A 3rd pitch continues as HDC 220.
